To proof.
The text is taken from a typescript copy supplied to the Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne by a descendant of Mrs Hogg. RB MSS number?
South Yarra, Melbourne

I have the honour, to inform you, that at the quarterly meeting of the Trustees of the Royal Park, held yesterday,
Is a copy of this letter in the minutes?
it was moved by myself and seconded by Mr Godfrey and was resolved, to express to you, your family and relatives, the profound condolence of the Trustees at the death of your revered father Dr Thomas Black,
Black died on 15 September 1894. whose autumn of life, you, Madam, have rendered particularly serene and cheerful, by filial solicitous attentiveness at his very advanced but bright age.

In conveying our deep sorrow at this irreparable loss to you, and those dear and near to you, the trustees feel, that they have lost in him the main originator of the Institution represented by them, who prominently shared in their obligations through a long series of years for administering the Royal Park, they always benefitting from his thoughtful counsel even to within the last year of his life; moreover they miss in him now a genial friend, whose memory they will bear in grateful remembrance.

It must have been, we feel, to Dr Black a source of continuous joy to have seen so flourishing a family in three generations arise around him, to have been identified leadingly with many of our public insitutions, to have carried with him the highest respect in wide circles of our population and to have witnessed this young colony almost from its very beginning, to advance to marvellous greatness; in the historic records.
The striving Pioneers and Leaders cannot sink into oblivion.
With profound condolence, I remain dear Madam,
